slidetranscripts.Text: This is a mandatory course which is designed to be taken prior to fit testing and must be repeated every two years. It is not intended to replace the hands on training given during fit testing, but instead will give officers knowledge of the respiratory program and provide a reference tool for officers to use when in the office. It also provides officers with information regarding infectious diseases they may encounter in the course of their duties.

After this course, learners will be able to:

Describe the use of one or more respirators used by the CBSA to protect against airborne hazards

Airborne contaminants may come in many forms including particles such as mould spores, viruses and drugs, fibres like asbestos, and gases and vapours such as carbon monoxide, hydrogen sulphide and fumes and mists. Different types of protection must be selected for each contaminant.
Airborne contaminants may enter the body through inhalation, ingestion via hand to mouth, absorption through the skin, mucous membranes or eyes or puncture wounds such as open cuts.

When upper respiratory tract irritation such as coughing and sneezing is experienced, this is the bodys natural system of protection at work.

Larger visible particles are of less concern as they are trapped by nose hairs.

Smaller particles, however, pose a greater risk as they can become trapped deeper in the lung causing long-term health effects.
Contaminants can also be ingested when hands become contaminated and are not washed adequately before eating, smoking, drinking, biting nails, etc.
In some cases, even when airborne levels are low, liquids and/or vapours can be absorbed through the skin, eyes or mucous membranes and cause adverse effects.

Open cuts are also of concern for exposure to liquids or vapours as contaminants may be absorbed into the blood stream.

It is extremely important to wear gloves when examining packages or luggage to prevent needles stick injuries or cuts from other sharp objects.

Under the Canada Labour Code, Part II and the Canada Occupational Health and Safety Regulations Part XII 12.7 - Safety Materials, Equipment, Devices and Clothing the following criteria must be met as listed.

·The OHS Division administers the Respiratory Protection Program at the Headquarters level.

·Regional Program Administrators have been assigned to manage the program locally.

·As per the Canada Labour Code Part II, managers, superintendents and employees also have assigned roles and responsibilities.

Please review the following roles and responsibilities and contact your Regional Program Administrator should you require

The Agency Program Administrator has the authority and overall responsibility to manage all aspects of the RPP and can be contacted through the Director of Occupational Health and Safety at 613-941-1032

To assist the Agency Program Administrator in exercising the overall authority to manage the RPP, the APA may delegate the above noted function(s) to a Procedural Program Administrator. They are selected on the basis of the program area in which respirators are required to be worn.

The chart displayed lists the Procedural Program Administrator for each program area

Regional Program Administrators (RPA):

·Liaise with Districts to ensure that the RPP is being administered and records kept as required;

·Liaise with Health Canada when medical assessments are required such as for Supplied Air Breathing Devices;

·Provide a summary of all records to the APA annually.
The Senior Manager of a workplace shall be considered the employer and is responsible for the program and its implementation within his/her workplace

The role of the Superintendent is to:

·Ensure all personnel under his/her control, who are designated to use respirators, are instructed, trained and remain knowledgeable in the safe use, operation and maintenance of these respirators;

·Ensure employees complete all forms and attend any medical appointments that may be necessary to determine fitness to wear a respirator;

·Provide all information pertaining to the types of respirators and working conditions to the Regional RPP Administrator;

·Ensure that only qualified staff use respiratory protection;

·Ensure respirator users comply with all facets of the RPP;

·Ensure that each respirator user is aware of every known or foreseeable health or safety hazard in the worksite;

·Ensure that employees do not enter workplaces where an unidentified contaminant has been detected and where the risks are unknown;

The role of the Superintendent is to:

·Ensure respirator users use and maintain respirators as described in this protocol;

·Attend training sessions on all the components of the RPP program;

·Ensure that respirator users are clean-shaven when using tight-fitting respirators and do not have any object or material that would interfere with the seal or operation of the respirator;

·Notify the RPA of any concerns that users may have regarding use of the respirators;

·Notify the RPA of investigation reports that revealed that the use of a respirator may have prevented or contributed to an incident or injury;

·Ensure that employees clean and inspect respirators following each use of a respirator; and

·Ensure that employees keep records of cleaning, inspection and maintenance following each use of a respirator.

All respiratory protection equipment users will:

·Attend training sessions on the safe use of respirators and not use or work in an area requiring respiratory protection unless properly trained and instructed;

·Complete the Health Canada Self Declaration Questionnaire for Respiratory Users

·If required, attend a medical evaluation to assess fitness as a user of respirators;

·Attend a medical assessment for users of respirators if you use a Supplied Air Respirator;

·Only don a tight fitting respirator if clean-shaven where the face piece seals to the skin.

All respiratory protection equipment users will:

·Use respirators according to written procedures and in the required circumstances;

·Inspect the respirator before and after each use;

·Clean the respirator following each use;

·Report any damage or malfunction of equipment immediately to his/her supervisor; and

·Complete the Cleaning, inspection and maintenance record after each use of a respirator
Regional Training Coordinators will notify employees when they require training and fit testing and will maintain training records.

Fit testers must:

·Be trained on fit testing procedures by a qualified service provider;

·Under no circumstances, perform a fit test unless the employee undergoing the fit test is clean-shaven where the face piece seals to the skin;

·Ensure that the employee does a positive and negative seal check prior to the fit test;

·Maintain records of fit tests and provide a summary of the fit tests to the Regional Training Coordinator.

Employees responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of Emergency Breathing Apparatus (EBA) and Supplied Air Breathing Apparatus (SABA) shall:

·Receive training on the inspection, maintenance and repair of the respirator systems according to the manufacturers instructions.

·Inspect, maintain and repair (or submit for maintenance and repairs) respirators, as required;

·Maintain records of inspection, repair and maintenance.

A N95 respirator refers to a disposable half mask respirator which can be used to protect against contaminants in particulate form.

The N95 respirator is used in close proximity to a person suspected of carrying an infectious disease and in the Examination of Goods.

Disposable N95 respirators are used in pandemic situations or when processing or interviewing individuals who are suspected of having a communicable disease subject to quarantine and are exhibiting active symptoms such as coughing and sneezing (examples: H1N1 and Tuberculosis)

If within 2 meters of the individual you must wear a N95 respirator and non-ventilated goggles.

Gloves must also be worn when handling potentially contaminated documents or examining luggage/goods.

Signs and symptoms of illness suggesting communicable diseases subject to quarantine include the exhibition of one or more of the following:

1.Appearing obviously unwell.

2.Coughing with blood

3.Having a fever accompanied by any of the following:

·Recent onset shortness of breath or difficulty breathing

·Repeated coughing

·Diarrhea

·Headache

·Recent confusion

·Skin rash; or bruising or bleeding without previous injury

Note: A traveller displaying some of the signs and symptoms mentioned may not necessarily have a communicable disease, however, officers must be aware of the possibility. Proceed with caution and contact the quarantine officer.

Although officers may be exposed to a wide variety of diseases while processing or interviewing individuals, certain diseases have been showing up more commonly than others in recent years.

It is important to note that respirators are your last line of defense.

Ensure your vaccinations are up to date. Immunizations and tests for BSOs and IEOs include:

·Tuberculin Skin Test

·Hepatitis B

·Tetanus, Diphtheria and Pertussis

·Mumps, Measles and Rubella

·Influenza and

·Varicella or chicken pox

Travel related vaccinations are also required for officers traveling overseas. Look through the following list for information regarding these diseases.
Look through the following list for information regarding these diseases

Usually, the people who get anthrax are those who work with infected animals. Anthrax cannot spread from one person to another.

Anthrax spores can affect the skin (cutaneous infection), the stomach (gastrointestinal infection) or the lungs (inhalational infection).

Since the terrorist events of September 11, some people in the United States have received letters or packages that contain anthrax spores. To date, this has not happened in Canada. There have been false alarms and hoaxes in Canada but no one has received anthrax in the mail and no one has been infected with anthrax.

If you open a letter or package that contains anthrax spores, you may get a skin or lung infection if you touch or breathe in the spores. Ensure you follow your local emergency procedures for handling of suspicious packages.

Avian influenza is a contagious viral infection that can affect all species of birds, domestic or wild. Human infection is rare.

Symptoms include: high fever, lower respiratory tract infection, difficulty breathing, hoarse voice and other influenza-like symptoms. Diarrhoea, vomiting, abdominal pain, chest pain, and bleeding from the nose and gums have also been reported as early symptoms in some patients.

Influenza typically starts with a headache, chills and cough, followed rapidly by fever, loss of appetite, muscle aches and fatigue, running nose, sneezing, watery eyes and throat irritation.

Most people will recover from influenza within a week to ten days, but some - including people with chronic conditions, such as diabetes and cancer - are at greater risk of more severe complications, such as pneumonia.

Remember to get your flu shot every year to help avoid this illness!

Cholera is a bacteria and infection usually occurs from drinking or eating contaminated water or food or being exposed to the bodily fluids of an infected person.

It is associated with rapid dehydration, which may be life-threatening. Risk of infection from travellers for Port of Entry personnel is extremely low.

Symptoms include: fever, diarrhea, vomiting, dehydration.

Measles is a highly infectious disease spread through direct contact with or inhalation of the secretions from an infected person's nose or mouth.

Less commonly, the virus spreads through contact with articles freshly soiled with nasal and throat secretions.

Measles affects all age groups and can be prevented by a vaccine. Port of Entry personnel should ensure their measles immunizations are up to date.

Symptoms of measles begin 7 to 18 days after infection and include fever, runny nose, drowsiness, irritability and red eyes.

Small white spots can appear on the inside of the mouth and throat.

Then, 3 to 7 days after the start of the symptoms, a red, blotchy rash appears on the face and then progresses down the body.

Complications include diarrhea, pneumonia and infections of the brain.

In developed countries 2 to 3 cases per 1,000 result in death.

Noroviruses are a group of viruses that cause gastroenteritis. This illness is often called the stomach flu, although it is not related to the flu which is a respiratory illness caused by the influenza virus.

Noroviruses are very contagious and can spread easily from person to person. People exposed to the virus usually develop symptoms of illness within 24 to 48 hours, but symptoms can occur as early as 12 hours after exposure. Infected people can be contagious from the moment they start feeling ill to at least three days after they have recovered. Some people may be contagious for as long as two weeks after recovery.

Symptoms include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and stomach cramps. Sometimes, people may have a low-grade fever, chills, headache, muscle aches and fatigue.

SARS is spread through close contact with someone who is infected with the SARS coronavirus. Examples of close contact include living in the same household, providing care to someone with SARS, or having direct contact with respiratory secretions and body fluids of someone affected by SARS.

To date, it appears that people with SARS are not contagious until they develop symptoms. This may take up to ten days from the time they were in close contact with someone who has SARS.

Symptoms include cough, shortness of breath, difficulty breathing and also may include chills, headaches, muscle aches, sore throat and diarrhea.

TB is not as contagious as many other diseases. Tuberculosis bacteria are spread through the air when someone with active TB disease of the lungs or airways exhales (when coughing, sneezing, singing, playing a wind instrument or, to a lesser extent, talking).

To become infected, you usually have to be exposed often to someone with active TB disease. For example, spending several hours a day with a person with active TB disease would put you at risk of infection. You cannot become infected with TB by shaking hands, sitting on toilet seats, or sharing dishes with someone who has TB.

It is important that BSOs and IEOs receive a baseline Tuberculin Skin Test (TST) in case of future potential exposure to a traveller with active TB. This will make treatment much easier should they acquire an infection.

Follow-up testing should be completed if exposed to someone with a confirmed active case of TB.

Disposable N95 respirators are used for protection against mould and particulates when examining goods.

Examples of particulates include narcotics and nuisance dusts

Health effects of exposure to particulates are varied and dependent on a number of factors such as the type of particle, shape, size, amount inhaled, time of exposure and personal health.

Any part of the respiratory system may be affected, depending on where the particles settle. The most significant health effects occur from smaller particles that settle deep in the lungs. Cigarette smoking may alter the ability of the lungs to clear themselves and increases risk significantly.

Prior to fit testing, employees must complete Health Canada Form - 4,"Self Declaration Questionnaire".

The purpose of the document is to identify those individuals who should receive further evaluation by Health Canada professionals.

If an employee answers "Yes" indicating that he/she may have problems wearing a respirator, Health Canada form 3321 must be completed and both forms sent to Health Canada. The employee will be contacted by a Health Canada professional for an appointment.

Both forms may be found in Appendix 1 of Health Canadas Occupational Health Assessment Guide.

Fit testing is extremely important to ensure that the face piece fits to your facial contour. Improperly fit leads to inward leakage of contaminated air.

The fit test must be repeated every 2 years or earlier if there are changes to facial features as a result of weight change, dental work, etc.

The fit test is only appropriate to the make, model and size of the respirator for which you had the fit test completed.

Fit testing is managed through your regional training coordinator.

You may not have a fit test if you have a beard or jewellery that interferes with the seal of the face piece.

Using the safety equipment

Officers should follow the procedures when donning and removing the N95, goggles, and gloves required when using the respirator.

Inspection of Face piece and Goggles

·Before donning the N95 and gloves, officers should ensure that they are in good condition and that the straps of the N95 are not brittle.

Donning and Use of Face Piece, Goggle, and Gloves

The following steps will help ensure that this is done properly every time the face piece is donned:

·Place the mask in the palm of one hand with the metal clip near your fingertips. The straps should hang down. Fit the mask over your nose and mouth with the metal clip over your nose.

·Pull the top strap over your head with your other hand and place it on the crown of your head.

·Pull the bottom strap over your head until it rests on your neck just below your ears.

·Using both hands and two fingers on each side, mold the metal nose clip around your nose starting at the top until it is securely sealed. Do not pinch the clip with one hand.

Seal Checks

Seal checks must be completed to ensure there are no leaks. These must be done each time you put on a respirator.

Negative Seal Check

·To complete a negative seal check, cover the face piece with both hands and inhale. The respirator should collapse slightly.

·If air leaks around the face piece seal, adjust the mask and nose clip and repeat.

Positive Seal Check

·Next complete a positive seal check by placing both hands completely over the mask and blow out gently. The mask should bulge slightly but not leak around the seal.

·If you feel air leak around the face piece seal, adjust the mask and nose clip.

··If you still feel a leak with either the negative pressure or positive pressure seal check, do not proceed with using the respirator. Another make/model of respirator should be tried.

Goggles

·Put on goggles ensuring they do not dislodge the respirator. Goggles should fit tightly around the eyes to prevent airborne contaminants from entering the eyes.

·Use clean, ungloved hands to grasp the straps or ties of the goggles and lift away from the face.

If contaminated, clean in warm soapy water. Rinse after washing.

Gloves

·Wear disposable gloves if handling potentially contaminated documents or packages.

Removal and Storage of equipment

When removing the equipment, they should be removed in the order presented as well as using the procedures outlined.

Glove removal

It is important to remove the gloves first, as they may be contaminated with pollutants which should be transferred to other surfaces.

·Upon completion of the task, first remove contaminated gloves by grasping the opposite glove near the wrist, pulling and peeling the glove away from the hand so that the contaminated side ends up inside out.

·Next while holding the removed glove in the remaining gloved hand, slide one or two fingers of the ungloved hand under the wrist of the remaining glove and peel the glove off from the inside.

·Discard in a standard waste receptacle and wash hands.

Goggle Removal

·Once the gloves have been removed, goggles may be safely removed.

·Store in a clean bag away from direct sunlight and extreme heat.

Respirator Removal

·Using clean hands, remove the respirator with the straps to avoid touching a potentially contaminated face piece.

·N95 respirators must be stored away from direct sunlight and extreme heat.

·If contaminated, place in a plastic bag and dispose in a regular garbage receptacle.

Donning 3-panel respirator

3 panel respirators must be donned according to manufacturer's instructions.

Recap

To recap, each time you use theN95 and associated safety equipment you must proceed as follows:

Inspection of face piece

·Inspect the face piece

Donning face piece and safety equipment

·Place face piece over nose and mouth.

·Pull top strap onto crown of head.

·Pull bottom strap over your head onto your neck.

·Mold nose clip around nose.

·Positive pressure seal check

·Negative pressure seal check

·Put on goggles making sure they do not dislodge the mask

·Put on gloves.

Removal

·Remove gloves

·Remove goggles

·Remove mask by straps

·Dispose gloves and mask

·Store respirators and goggles away from direct sunlight and extreme heat

Do not use an N95 in atmospheres containing less than 19.5% oxygen,

In atmospheres that are Immediately Dangerous to Life and Health (IDLH), Or for protection against chemical vapours.

Nor should an N95 be used by officers with facial hair or other conditions that interfere with the seal between the face and the respirator,

If altered or abused

Or a model for which you have not been fit tested
Choose the respirator type you would like to learn more about. You can always come back to this screen to learn about another one at the end of the module

At CBSA, the P100 refers to half mask re-usable respirators with P100 filters.

The P100 is to be used in vessel rummage and examination of goods.

A re-usable half mask respirator with P100 filters must be worn where there is potential of exposure to asbestos while searching marine vessels.

The Rummage Coordinator will determine, in consultation with the ships Captain, whether asbestos-containing materials may be present.

If the presence of ACMs is confirmed or the Captain is unable to confirm the presence or absence of ACMs, proceed according to the Rummage Procedures as shown in on-line course Asbestos on Marine Vessels and wear a P100 respirator.

Inhaled asbestos fibres can be transported deep into the lungs and once embedded in the lung tissue, remain for long periods of time. It takes at least 10 and often 20 or 30 years before health effects are noticed. Exposure to asbestos can lead to pleural thickening, asbestosis, lung cancer or mesothelioma.

The P100 may also be used when examining goods.

When examining goods P100 respirators are used for protection against mould and particulates.

Examples of particulates include narcotics and nuisance dusts

Health effects of exposure to particulates are varied and dependent on a number of factors such as the type of particle, shape, size, amount inhaled, time of exposure and personal health.

Any part of the respiratory system may be affected, depending on where the particles settle. The most significant health effects occur from smaller particles that settle deep in the lungs. Cigarette smoking may alter the ability of the lungs to clear themselves and increases risk significantly.

Prior to fit testing, employees must complete Health Canada Form - 4,"Self Declaration Questionnaire".

The purpose of the document is to identify those individuals who should receive further evaluation by Health Canada professionals.

If an employee answers "Yes" indicating that he/she may have problems wearing a respirator, Health Canada form 3321 must be completed and both forms sent to Health Canada. The employee will be contacted by a Health Canada professional for an appointment.

Both forms may be found in Appendix 1 of Health Canadas Occupational Health Assessment Guide.

Fit testing is extremely important to ensure that the face piece fits to your facial contour. Improperly fit leads to inward leakage of contaminated air

The fit test must be repeated every 2 years or earlier if there are changes to facial features as a result of weight change, dental work, etc.

The fit test is only appropriate to the make, model and size of the respirator for which you had the fit test completed

Fit testing is managed through your regional training coordinator

You may not have a fit test if you have a beard or jewellery that interferes with the seal of the face piece

This video will describe the procedures officers must be aware of when donning, removing and cleaning the P100.

Preparing to don:

First, the equipment must be inspected. In order to complete a full inspection, the steps presented here must be followed:

·Inspect the face piece for dirt, cracks and distortion.

·Examine the 2 inhalation valves and ensure gaskets and valves are in place.

·Remove the cover of the exhalation valve. Inspect and ensure that all parts of the exhalation valve are in place and intact.

·Verify the elasticity of the head straps

·Replace defective parts with parts from the same make and model. Do not use parts from another model of respirator.


Finally, filters must be secured

·Place the P100 filters on the inhalation valves. Ensure that they click into place and are secure.

Donning

Follow the steps presented here to ensure that the P100 is properly donned:

·With the bottom strap undone, place the face piece over your nose and chin. Hold it in place with one hand.

·With your other hand, pull the harness so that it rests on the crown of your head.

·Connect the bottom straps behind your neck.

·Adjust the straps so they are comfortable. Do not tighten them too much or the respirator will be uncomfortable to wear.


Once the face piece is in place, both a negative and positive seal check must be performed in order to ensure that there are no leaks. This must be done each time the respirator is donned.

Negative Seal Check

·Close off the inhalation valves using your thumbs or palm of your hand, depending on the style of filter.

·Inhale gently, and hold your breath for at least 5 seconds. If the face piece collapses slightly and no inward leakage of air is detected, the seal should be sufficient.

·If air leaks around the face piece seal, adjust the mask and straps and repeat.

Positive Seal Check

·Close off the exhalation valve using the palm of your hand and exhale gently for at least 5 seconds. You should feel a slight positive pressure build up inside the face piece without detecting any outward leakage of air between the sealing surface of the face piece and your face.

·If air leaks around the face piece seal, adjust the mask and straps and repeat.

·If you still feel a leak during either the negative seal check or the positive pressure seal check, do not proceed with using the respirator. You should request a different make or model of the respirator.


In cases where officers may be wearing other personal protection equipment such as hearing protectors or hard hats, ensure that they do not interfere with the fit of the respirator.


Removal

In order to remove the P100, follow these steps:

·Loosen the straps. Unclip the strap around the neck. Remove the mask while maintaining your hold on the straps.

·Remove the filters and dispose of them in a garbage receptacle.

·If the filter has potentially been exposed to asbestos, it should be disposed.

Cleaning and Storage

In order to ensure that respirators are properly stored for future use, they must be washed after each time they are used. The following procedure will help ensure that this is done properly:

·To clean the respirator, first remove the head harness, exhalation cover, diaphragms and exhalation valve assemblies.

·Wash the face piece in warm water with dish detergent or cleaner recommended by the manufacturer. Wash components separately from the face piece, as necessary.

·Rinse thoroughly in clean warm water to remove all traces of detergent. This step is very important to prevent dermatitis in respirator users.

·Air dry or dry with a clean dry cloth

·Respirators and filters should be stored separately in a clean plastic bag away from extreme heat or direct sunlight.

Recap

To recap, each time you use the respirator you must proceed as follows:

Preparing to Don

·Inspect the respirator

·Put filters in place

Donning

·Place face piece over nose and mouth.

·Pull head harness onto crown of head.

·Connect the bottom straps behind your neck.

·Adjust straps.

·Complete a negative Seal check

·Complete a positive Seal check

·Ensure other personal protective equipment does not affect the seal of the facepiece.

Removal

·Loosen straps and unclip the strap behind the neck.

·Remove respirator

·Remove filters and discard

Cleaning and Storage

·Wash respirator

·Store filter and respirator in separate clean plastic bags
Do not use the P100 in any of the circumstances listed below

Each time the respirator is used, it must be recorded in the table found in Appendix G of the CBSA Respiratory Protection Program.

Copies of this record must be provided to the Regional Program Administrator annually.
Choose the respirator type you would like to learn more about. You can always come back to this screen to learn about another one at the end of the module

An EBA is a portable air system providing the user with a limited amount of breathable air to enable self-rescue in an atmospheric emergency.

CBSA uses Survivair EBA-10 systems which provide 10 minutes of emergency breathing air giving the user time to safely escape from toxic or oxygen-deficient atmospheres. The EBA is stored in a carrying case to enable the officer to carry the unit from site to site during a rummage and can easily be donned in an emergency. Breathable air is delivered into the hood as soon as the valve is opened creating a positive pressure environment inside the hood preventing toxic gases from entering the breathing zone.

EBAs must be carried by officers during rummage of vessels carrying petroleum products. This includes Oil tankers, Gas Carriers and Special-Use Tankers.

Officers must also wear gas detectors during the rummage. The detectors will alert officers when the following atmospheric hazards exist:

·Oxygen deficiency

·High carbon monoxide

·High hydrogen sulphide

·Flammability as Lower Explosive Limit -- the lowest concentration of a gas that has the potential to combust

Alarms are set on the gas monitors at two levels. Low alarm set points provide initial warning of an unsafe condition at which point officers will prepare to evacuate. High alarm set points indicate that conditions are worsening and officers must immediately evacuate.

The following section covers the inspection, use, donning, use, cleaning and storage of the EBA

Inspection

The EBA must be inspected after each use and once every 30 days. All damaged parts must be replaced. Defective or non-functioning devices will be tagged out of service and shall be removed from service until repaired.

The following 5 parts must be inspected:

·Inspect the indicator to ensure it is not deformed or stuck. The pointer mus be in the green area

·Remove the hood from its pouch and inspect for rips, tears, holes and ensure that the drawstring is functioning

·Ensure the breathing tube is in good condition and that the hose is clamped securely to the regulator

·Inspect the cylinder for dents, gouges or cuts

·Defective or damaged parts msut be replaced

Donning respirator in case of emergency

In case of emergency, don the respirator as follows:

·Pull Open flap to access the flow valve and hood.

·Remove the hood and unfold it.

·Remove your hardhat.

·Open the valve completely ensuring that the hood fills with air.

·Position the hood on your head with the red elbow of the breathing tube near your mouth.

·Tighten the drawstring only enough to keep the hood in place.

·Replace your hardhat overtop of the hood.

·Calmly move to the predetermined safe zone.

·Once in the safe zone, remove the hood and turn off the valve, inspect the cylinder and return for refilling.

Cleaning

·After use, clean the hood with mild soap and warm water. Rinse thoroughly and wipe dry or air dry.

Storage

·Cylinders must be stored in an upright position

·Hoods must be folded as shown in training and stored away from sources of excessive heat or cold

·Avoid storing in your car in sub-zero temperatures or extremely hot temperatures as the pressure within the cylinder may be affected

Normal oxygen concentration in air is 21%.
A minimum of 18% and a maximum of 23% oxygen are considered to be safe levels. CBSA gas monitors are set to alarm when a lower level of 19.5% is reached in order to provide an additional level of safety.

Symptoms when exposed to low concentrations of oxygen are found in the chart shown.

Increased carbon monoxide concentration interferes with the ability of blood to carry oxygen to tissues and the brain.

The chart shown details the effects of increased carbon monoxide concentrations. Alarm set points on the gas monitor are set to activate when levels reach 10% and 100% of the maximum permissible exposure limit.

Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) is a deadly gas and when exposed to high levels a worker may pass out quickly and death may follow in seconds or minutes due to breathing failure. The chart listed summarizes the symptoms.

The maximum permitted 8-hour exposure is 1 part per million and 5 parts per million for a 15 minute exposure. The low alarm is set at 1 part per million and the high alarm is set at 50% of the maximum permitted 15-minute exposure.

The gas monitor also measures for the Lower Explosive Limit which is the lowest concentration of gas in a mixture that has the potential to cause a fire or explosion.

The gas monitor is set up to alarm when 15% of the L.E.L. is reached which gives sufficient time to put on the EBA and escape.

Employees who use the EBA must undergo a Category III medical for Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA) at Health Canada. This can be done at the same time as the Category III medical completed by all employees with enforcement duties by checking off SCBA on the electronic version of form HC/SC 3312. By checking off SCBA, additional questions pertaining to your ability to wear a supplied air respirator will be included.
The following list of emergency procedures must be followed should the gas monitor alarm sound or fail.
Choose the respirator type you would like to learn more about. You can always come back to this screen to learn about another one at the end of the module

The SABA consists of a full facepiece respirator attached to a source of compressed breathing air supplied from a tank or compressor. It may also include an emergency escape air cylinder for use if the air system fails. Components include some or all of the following: full facepiece, demand valve, breathing tube, harnesses, couplers, air hose, emergency escape air cylinders and compressed breathing air cylinder.
The SABA must be used in unknown atmospheres and at Container Examinations Facilities

Air supplied respirators must always be used where contaminant levels are unknown or in IDLH situations.

Combination supplied-air with auxiliary self-contained air supply must be used for IDLH situations.

Chemical fumigants are widely used in the shipping industry in cargo loads to preserve cargo. These chemicals can be harmful to human health if precautionary measures are not followed. Currently cargo containers that are targeted for examination are tested prior to entry for the 10 most common fumigants found in containers. If levels are high the containers are ventilated using doors fitted with exhaust fans such as Nordiko doors.

SABAs are used when installing ventilation doors on containers which have been tested with high Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) or Immediately Dangerous to Life or Health (IDLH) environments to prevent over-exposure to chemical vapours.

Please refer to the attached Fumigant Program User Guide for specific requirements and procedures.
The following chart is a summary of symptoms which may be experienced when exposed to the 10 most common fumigants found in fumigated containers.

Employees who use the SABA must undergo a Category III medical for Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA) at Health Canada. This can be done at the same time as the Category III medical completed by all employees with enforcement duties by checking off SCBA on the electronic version of form HC/SC 3312. By checking off SCBA, additional questions pertaining to your ability to wear a supplied air respirator will be included.

Each time the respirator is used, it must be recorded in the table found in Appendix G of the CBSA Respiratory Protection Program.

Copies of this record must be provided to the Regional Program Administrator annually.
Choose the respirator type you would like to learn more about. You can always come back to this screen to learn about another one at the end of the module

CSA groups respirators into 3 categories:

1. Air-Purifying. Air is filtered through filters/cartridges or through a filtering facepiece.

CSA groups respirators into 3 categories:

2. Escape-only: The respirator facepiece (hood or mask) is attached to a cylinder containing 5, 10, or 15 minutes of breathing air.

CSA groups respirators into 3 categories:

3. Atmosphere supplying: Compressed breathing air is supplied from a cylinder or compressor.
Respirator filters and filtering facepieces are classified by NIOSH as shown in this table.

Cartridges are used to remove gases or chemical vapours. Combination cartridges may also be used which also have a filter layer for removal of particulate aerosols. Cartridges are assigned colour codes. For example, the olive coloured multi-contaminant with P100 filter will protect against certain organic vapours, acid gases and particulates. Note that this cartridge will not protect against all chemical vapours such as mercury and formaldehyde. Specific cartridges are needed for those contaminants.

Hazard assessments completed by the Program Area in consultation with the Agency Program Administrator have selected four types of respirators suitable for potentially hazardous tasks performed by CBSA officers.
